trans-unit.target: Summary:

trans-unit.source: Determining which application pattern or patterns to use for your SQL Server based applications in Azure environment is an important design decision and it requires a solid understanding of how SQL Server and each infrastructure component of Azure work together.
trans-unit.target: Determining which application pattern or patterns to use for your SQL Server based applications in Azure environment is an important design decision and it requires a solid understanding of how SQL Server and each infrastructure component of Azure work together.

trans-unit.source: With SQL Server in Azure Infrastructure Services, you can easily migrate, maintain, and monitor your existing SQL Server applications built-on Windows Server to virtual machines in Azure.
trans-unit.target: With SQL Server in Azure Infrastructure Services, you can easily migrate, maintain, and monitor your existing SQL Server applications built-on Windows Server to virtual machines in Azure.

trans-unit.source: The goal of this article is to provide solution architects and developers a foundation for good application architecture and design, which they can follow when migrating existing applications to Azure as well as developing new applications in Azure.
trans-unit.target: The goal of this article is to provide solution architects and developers a foundation for good application architecture and design, which they can follow when migrating existing applications to Azure as well as developing new applications in Azure.

trans-unit.target: For each application pattern, you will find an on-premises scenario, its respective cloud-enabled solution, and the related technical recommendations.

trans-unit.source: Introduction
trans-unit.target: Introduction

trans-unit.source: You can develop many types of n-tier applications by separating the components of the different application layers on different machines as well as in separate components.
trans-unit.target: You can develop many types of n-tier applications by separating the components of the different application layers on different machines as well as in separate components.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can place the client application and business rules components in one machine, front-end web tier and data access tier components in another machine, and a back-end database tier in another machine.
trans-unit.target: For example, you can place the client application and business rules components in one machine, front-end web tier and data access tier components in another machine, and a back-end database tier in another machine.

trans-unit.source: This kind of structuring helps isolate each tier from each other.
trans-unit.target: This kind of structuring helps isolate each tier from each other.

trans-unit.source: If you change where data comes from, you don’t need to change the client or web application but only the data access tier components.
trans-unit.target: If you change where data comes from, you don’t need to change the client or web application but only the data access tier components.

trans-unit.source: Presentation
trans-unit.target: Presentation

trans-unit.source: The *presentation tier* (web tier, front-end tier) is the layer in which users interact with an application.
trans-unit.target: The *presentation tier* (web tier, front-end tier) is the layer in which users interact with an application.

trans-unit.source: Business
trans-unit.target: Business

trans-unit.source: The *business tier* (middle tier) is the layer that the presentation tier and the data tier use to communicate with each other and includes the core functionality of the system.
trans-unit.target: The *business tier* (middle tier) is the layer that the presentation tier and the data tier use to communicate with each other and includes the core functionality of the system.

trans-unit.source: Data
trans-unit.target: Data

trans-unit.source: The *data tier* is basically the server that stores an application's data (for example, a server running SQL Server).
trans-unit.target: The *data tier* is basically the server that stores an application's data (for example, a server running SQL Server).

trans-unit.source: Application layers describe the logical groupings of the functionality and components in an application; whereas tiers describe the physical distribution of the functionality and components on separate physical servers, computers, networks, or remote locations.
trans-unit.target: Application layers describe the logical groupings of the functionality and components in an application; whereas tiers describe the physical distribution of the functionality and components on separate physical servers, computers, networks, or remote locations.

trans-unit.source: The layers of an application may reside on the same physical computer (the same tier) or may be distributed over separate computers (n-tier), and the components in each layer communicate with components in other layers through well-defined interfaces.
trans-unit.target: The layers of an application may reside on the same physical computer (the same tier) or may be distributed over separate computers (n-tier), and the components in each layer communicate with components in other layers through well-defined interfaces.

trans-unit.source: You can think of the term tier as referring to physical distribution patterns such as two-tier, three-tier, and n-tier.
trans-unit.target: You can think of the term tier as referring to physical distribution patterns such as two-tier, three-tier, and n-tier.

trans-unit.source: A **2-tier application pattern** contains two application tiers: application server and database server.
trans-unit.target: A **2-tier application pattern** contains two application tiers: application server and database server.

trans-unit.source: The direct communication happens between the application server and the database server.
trans-unit.target: The direct communication happens between the application server and the database server.

trans-unit.source: The application server contains both web-tier and business-tier components.
trans-unit.target: The application server contains both web-tier and business-tier components.

trans-unit.source: In **3-tier application pattern**, there are three application tiers: web server, application server, which contains the business logic tier and/or business tier data access components, and the database server.
trans-unit.target: In **3-tier application pattern**, there are three application tiers: web server, application server, which contains the business logic tier and/or business tier data access components, and the database server.

trans-unit.source: The communication between the web server and the database server happens over the application server.
trans-unit.target: The communication between the web server and the database server happens over the application server.

trans-unit.target: In this application pattern, you deploy your SQL Server application and database to a standalone virtual machine in Azure.
